column1: {"body": " (AP) \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Donald Trump couldn't beat the team of Jimmy Fallon and Justin Timberlake.\nLast Saturday's Trump-hosted \"Saturday Night Live\" averaged 9.3 million viewers
column2: according to final Nielsen figures released Thursday.\nNBC says it's the most-watched edition of \"SNL\" since December 2013
column3: when Fallon guest-hosted
column4: joined by musical guest Timberlake. That broadcast drew 9.4 million viewers.\nTrump's appearance had been highly anticipated and sparked controversy in the aftermath of remarks made by the GOP presidential hopeful about Mexican immigrants. The show
column5: which also featured musical guest Sia
column6: was roundly panned by critics."

column1: {"body": " (CNN)A conservative activist best known for questioning President Barack Obama's religion is challenging Bernie Sanders qualifications for the Democratic ballot in New Hampshire. \nAndy Martin
column2: who has filed himself as a Republican presidential candidate in New Hampshire
column3: argued in a complaint to the New Hampshire secretary of state's office that Sanders had no standing to run in the Democratic primary.\n\"Mr. Sanders claims that he can run as a Democrat in New Hampshire 'because there is no party registration in Vermont.' The claim is a complete red herring
column4:
" Martin writes in his complaint filed on Thursday. 
Sanders is an independent who caucuses with Democrats in the Senate.
Martin gained some fame during the Obama's first White House run for his claim that Obama was a Muslim. The New York Times reported in 2008 that Martin spread the rumor in a 2004 press release "Obama is a Muslim who has concealed his religion."
Sanders strategist Tad Devine said Thursday he wasn't worried about Martin's challenge. 
"I'm sure they have a process
column5: whatever their process is we'll deal with the process
column6: \" Devine said of how the secretary of state's office handles complaints. \"He has declared his standing as a Democratic candidate publicly
column8: did so when he filed his declaration of candidacy.\"\n"
column10: "description": "A conservative activist best known for questioning President Barack Obama's religion is challenging Bernie Sanders qualifications for the Democratic ballot in New Hampshire."
column11: "title": "Anti-Obama activist challenges Sanders"

column1: {"body": "Students held demonstrations on university campuses across the United States on Thursday to protest ballooning student loan debt for higher education and rally for tuition-free public colleges.\nThe demonstrations
column2: dubbed the Million Student March
column3: were planned just two days after thousands of fast-food workers took to the streets in a nationwide day of action pushing for a $15-an-hour minimum wage and union rights for the industry.\nAbout 50 students from Boston-area colleges gathered at Northeastern University carrying signs that read \"Degrees not receipts\" and \"Is this a school or a corporation?\"\n\"The student debt crisis is awful. Change starts when people demand it in the street. Not in the White House
column4: \" said Elan Axelbank
column6: a third year student at Northeastern
column7: who said he was a co-founder of the national action.\nPhotos and videos posted on Twitter
column8: where #MillionStudentMarch was trending worldwide
column9: showed marches involving dozens to hundreds of demonstrators at schools including Texas State
column10: the University of Massachusetts at Amherst and Depaul University in Chicago.\nA few hundred students rallied on the campus of the historically progressive University of California Berkeley
column11: and posted placards on the outside of a class building showing their individual student debt loads
column12: ranging from just several thousand dollars to more than $100
column14: cancellation of all student debt and a $15-an-hour minimum wage for campus workers.\nThe total volume of outstanding U.S. student loan debt has more than doubled to $1.2 trillion
column15: according to the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
column16: compared with less than $600 billion in 2006.\nSaddled with debt that can sometimes run into hundreds of thousands of dollars
column17: many college graduates struggle to make payments amid an ailing economy and job market.\nDealing with swiftly mounting student loan debt has been a focus of candidates vying for the White House in 2016.\nDemocratic hopeful Bernie Sanders
column18: who has vowed to make tuition free at public universities and colleges
column19: and has pledged to cut interest rates for student loans
column20: tweeted in support of the movement on Thursday afternoon.\nHis rival Hillary Clinton has said she would increase access to tuition grants
column21: let graduates refinance loans at lower interest rates
column22: and streamline income-based repayment plans.\nFlorida U.S. Senator Marco Rubio
column23: the most prominent Republican candidate to lay out a concrete proposal
column24: says he would establish an income-based repayment system for federal student loans and would simplify applications for federal aid.\nDemonstrators on Thursday also widened their message to echo protests at the University of Missouri
column25: three days after the school's former president resigned amid student anger over failure to address racial discrimination on campus.\n\n (Reporting by Curtis Skinner in San Francisco and Valerie Vande Panne in Boston; Additional reporting by Emmett Berg in Berkeley
column26: California and Elizabeth Barber in New York City; Editing by James Dalgleish and Diane Craft)"
column28: "description": "(Reuters) - Students held demonstrations on university campuses across the United States on Thursday to protest ballooning student loan debt for higher education and rally for tuition-free public colleges."

                        The controversial businessman may work with Rick Reed
column18:
a chief architect of the Swift Boat attack on Kerry.

            By 
Alex Isenstadt

11/12/15 11:58 AM EST
Donald Trump’s team has been in talks with Rick Reed
column19: a veteran Republican operative known for his bare-knuckle TV ad campaigns
column20: according to two sources familiar with the discussions. \nReed
column22: has served as a strategist for a number of conservative causes. During the 2004 presidential race
column23: he was a chief architect of the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth effort to take down John Kerry. He has previously worked for a number of congressional Republicans
column24: including South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham and former Virginia Sen. George Allen. He also spent years as a top operative for the National Republican Senatorial Committee.\nStory Continued Below\nIt was not clear
column26: whether Reed had formally signed on with the Trump campaign. \nNeither Reed nor spokespersons for Trump responded to multiple requests for comment in recent days
column27: and neither side would confirm or deny that talks had taken place.\nDespite his personal wealth
column29: who remains the front-runner in the Republican presidential primary contest
column30: has yet to commit to spending a substantial amount of money on TV ads to boost his candidacy. The real estate mogul
column33: 000 in a slate of radio commercials airing in early primary states. \n \u00a9 2015 POLITICO LLC"

column1: {"body": "Washington (CNN)Donald Trump insisted on Thursday that the U.S. must keep wages low in order to compete with other countries
column2: one day after he dug in on his assertion that \"wages are too high\" in America.\n\"Whether it's taxes or wages
column3: if they're too high we're not going to be able to compete with other countries
column4: \" Trump said Thursday morning on Fox News.\nTrump first said he believes wages are \"too high\" during Tuesday night's Republican debate
column5: undercutting the populist tone Trump has struck on the campaign trail as he's called for protecting U.S. manufacturing jobs from outsourcing and immigration.\nTrump's comments about wages being \"too high\" came in response to a debate question about raising the minimum wage
column6: which Trump and other GOP candidates said they oppose.\n\"Our taxes are too high. Our wages are too high. We have to compete with other countries
column7: \" Trump said again on Wednesday morning in an interview on MSNBC's \"Morning Joe
column8: \" where he was pressed on whether people can live on the current federal minimum wage of $7.25.\n"
column10: "description": "Donald Trump insisted on Thursday that the U.S. must keep wages low in order to compete with other countries
column11: one day after he dug in on his assertion that \"wages are too high\" in America."
column12: "title": "Trump digs in on 'wages too high' comment"

{"body": "WASHINGTONTwo U.S. consumer groups
announced the formation of a coalition with New York labor
unions on Thursday to press antitrust regulators to oppose big
insurance mergers that would cut the number of nationwide
for-profit health insurers from five to three.
The Coalition to Preserve Patient Choice
column2: made up of the\nConsumer Federation of America
column3: Consumer Action and others
column4:
was
formed because of concern about Anthem Inc's purchase
of Cigna Corp for $47 billion and Aetna Inc's 
decision to buy Humana Inc for $37 billion
column5:
the group
said in a statement.
"The CPPC believes these mergers should be challenged or
patient choice will suffer. In fact
column6: studies have shown previous\nhealth insurance mergers resulted in (price) increases ranging\nfrom 7 percent to nearly 14 percent
column7: \" the group said.\nAnthem said in a statement that the coalition's assertions\nwere \"misleading
column8:
" and that it was "confident that the
transaction's consumer benefits will be understood by state and
federal regulators."
Aetna said in a statement that its deal for Humana was
"primarily about the Medicare marketplace
column9: where there is robust\ncompetition and choice. We are confident that our transaction\nwill receive a fair
column10:
thorough and fact-based review from the
Department of Justice and the states."
The deals are being reviewed by the U.S. Department of
Justice and state insurance regulators
column11: and have been the\nsubject of hearings in Congress. They have also been criticized\nby Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton
column12:
who said
last month that she is "very skeptical" the mergers would be
good for consumers.
The American Medical Association has asked for the deals to
be blocked while the American Hospital Association has also been
critical of them.
(Reporting by Diane Bartz; Editing by Marguerita Choy and Tom
Brown)"
column15: Nov 12 (Reuters) - Two U.S. consumer groups announced the formation of a coalition with New York labor unions on Thursday to press antitrust regulators to oppose big insurance mergers..."
column16: "title": "Consumer coalition forms to fight U.S. health insurance mergers"

                AP Photo

                        Practically the entire GOP field is throwing around accusations
column17:
but the fight between the two senators got especially nasty.

            By 
Daniel Strauss

11/12/15 03:07 PM EST

                    Updated 11/12/15 03:40 PM EST
The immigration squabble among the Republican presidential contenders has turned into an all-out brawl between Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio
column18: with the two senators challenging each other's conservative credentials on the hot-button issue.\nWhile they were by no means the only GOP candidates throwing around immigration accusations on Thursday
column19: the intensity was the highest between Cruz and Rubio
column20: seen as two of the strongest ascending members of the Republican field
column21: especially after Tuesday's fourth debate.\nStory Continued Below\n\"They fought tooth and nail to try and jam this amnesty down the American people's throats
column22: \" Cruz said in an interview with conservative radio host Laura Ingraham on Thursday
column23: speaking about the \"Gang of Eight\" senators. Rubio's membership in the group
column24: which unsuccessfully shepherded a comprehensive immigration reform effort in 2013
column25: has haunted him since.\n\"Talk is cheap
column27: saying Rubio's actions disprove any claim that he's as conservative as Cruz on the topic. Cruz later added that the Florida senator opposed a set of amendments introduced by Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) and himself. \n\"He opposed every single one of them
column29: \" Cruz said. \"The 'Gang of Eight' voted as a gang against enforcing and securing the border.\" \nRubio
column30: in roughly the same bracket of hours Thursday morning
column31: took a few shots at Cruz while campaigning in South Carolina
column32:
hitting the Texas senator from the right.



            By 
Nick Gass

"Ted is a supporter of legalizing people that are in this country illegally. In fact
column33: when the Senate bill was proposed
column34: he proposed legalizing people that were here illegally
column35: \" Rubio said during a campaign stop in Hilton Head
column36: according to a readout from his campaign. \"He proposed giving them work permits. He's also supported a massive expansion of the green cards. He supported a massive expansion of the H-1B program
column39: I don't think our positions are dramatically different. I do believe that we have to deal with immigration reform in a serious way
column40: and it begins by proving to people that illegal immigration is under control.\" \nA Cruz aide shot back that Rubio's comments were not an accurate indicator of where the Texas senator stands on immigration. \n\"Laughably FALSE. No one fought harder to prevent Gang of 8's amnesty bill than Ted Cruz. Record is remarkably clear
column41: \" Cruz rapid response director Brian Phillips tweeted. \nThe tinder fueling the fighting between Cruz and Rubio has been growing for some time now. Cruz has styled himself as a hard-liner on immigration reform
column42: and opponents of Rubio often accuse him of flipping back and forth on immigration reform
column43: notably taking a rightward turn recently in throwing his support behind legislation cracking down on sanctuary cities. \nOther candidates looked to join in on the skirmishing that started during Tuesday night debate's in Milwaukee. Former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum tried to get into the mix by tweeting out on Thursday a link to a clip of Cruz describing how he's introduced \"two amendments to significantly expand legal immigration
column44: to double the caps on legal immigration from 675
column45: 000 to 1.3 million and to increase temporary high skilled workers by 500 percent.\"\nIt is clear what candidate is not a real conservative on immigration. Watch @tedcruz in 2013. https://t.co/TlCUYfgOi4\n\u2014 Rick Santorum (@RickSantorum) November 12
column47: in a separate interview with Ingraham
column48: moved to jab Rubio on his tax plan by tying it to immigration. \n\"I think Rubio's plan would explode payments to illegal aliens. And this is a real problem. Until we fix the current tax credits
column49: do we really want to double and triple the amount of tax credits we're giving? I mean really
column50: $4 billion to illegal aliens? I think Rubio's tax plan will extend more tax credits to illegal aliens
column51: and I think there's no way in the world that we should be supporting something like this
column52:
" Paul said. 



            By 
Seung Min Kim

Immigration has become a central litmus test among conservatives this cycle
column53: especially after billionaire Donald Trump kicked off his presidential run with a bold promise to build a massive wall along the U.S.-Mexico border and later pledged to deport more than 11 million undocumented immigrants. He noticeably pushed the field further right on the issue
column54: after the Republican Party tried to find a more central position in the wake of Mitt Romney's bruising loss in 2012.\nThe two candidates currently leading in the polls \u2014 Trump and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson \u2014 also tangled in the wake of Tuesday's debate. \nCarson said in an interview with The Washington Examiner on Wednesday that Trump's moves to build a wall along the border would backfire in the long run. \"I think there are enough people who know that there are others in the race that are very reasonable
column55: \" Carson said. \"I don't think he necessarily is the representation of the Republican Party \u2014 far from it.\"\nOn Thursday
column59: who is very weak on illegal Immigration
column60: just said he likes amnesty and a pathway to citizenship.\"\nIt wasn't the first time on Thursday that Trump banged the stronger borders drum
column63: either have borders or we don't. IF WE DON'T HAVE BORDERS
column64: WE DON'T HAVE A COUNTRY!\"\nEliza Collins contributed to this report. \n \u00a9 2015 POLITICO LLC"
column66: "description": "Practically the entire GOP field is throwing around accusations
column67: but the fight between the two senators got especially nasty."
column68: "title": "Immigration brawl breaks out between Cruz and Rubio"

column1: {"body": " (AP) \u00e2\u0080\u0094 President Barack Obama says Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's proposal to deport millions of undocumented immigrants is unrealistic and would cost the nation hundreds of billions of dollars.\nIn an interview Thursday with ABC News
column2: Obama suggests imagining the images on screens flashed around the world as parents are dragged away from their children
column3:
put in detention centers and systematically sent out of the country.
He says that's not "who we are as Americans."
Trump has said the U.S. can successfully and humanely deport the estimated 11 million people living in the country illegally with a deportation force.
Obama attributes cheers for the plan to a strain of anti-immigrant sentiment in American. He says it's the job of leaders not to play into that sentiment."

column1: {"body": "Shortly after Mayor Bill de Blasio and his national advocacy group trumpeted plans last month to hold a presidential forum in Iowa
column2: the mayor hopped on a conference call to rev up the liberal faithful.\n\nAddressing members from around the country
column3: the mayor spoke of girding for a sustained war on inequality \u2014 the very topic of the Dec. 6 forum
column4: which organizers believed would be a harbinger of the group\u2019s intent to play on the national stage.\n\nThose plans collapsed this week. The de Blasio-backed group canceled its event
column5: explaining in a statement that it would redirect its energies into other methods of tackling inequality.\n\nOn Wednesday
column6: Mr. de Blasio acknowledged a more humbling reality: Not a single presidential candidate had agreed to attend.\n\nThe disintegration of the Iowa conclave was the most significant setback yet for the Progressive Agenda Committee
column7: an ambitious but halting enterprise that has prompted questions about Mr. de Blasio\u2019s political judgment
column8: and has tested his clout as a local official with baldly ideological aspirations.\n\nMr. de Blasio and his allies say the group is a necessary vehicle to rally liberal elites behind a cohesive message. Inspired by a policy agenda that Mr. de Blasio unveiled in Washington in May
column9: covering topics from union rights to international trade
column10: the Progressive Agenda Committee is now incorporated as a nonprofit
column11: with its own executive director and political director.\n\nBut the project
column12: founded by Mr. de Blasio and backed by influential labor leaders and former City Hall aides
column13: has faced a series of unexpected setbacks: Prominent elected officials have hesitated to commit themselves. Some leaders who endorsed Mr. de Blasio\u2019s policy manifesto have had second thoughts about promoting such a grandly ideological document.\n\nEven the rise of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont in the presidential race has presented a challenge for the Progressive Agenda
column14: forcing the group to reconsider its goals now that a self-described socialist has already electrified the Democratic primary with heated rhetoric about inequality. (Mr. de Blasio endorsed Hillary Rodham Clinton last month.)\n\nThe project has also sharply divided advisers to Mr. de Blasio
column15: some of whom counseled the mayor to reconsider the Iowa forum
column16: concerned that it had deepened perceptions of Mr. de Blasio as excessively preoccupied with national politics
column17: according to people familiar with their reservations.\n\nThese people
column18: who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss private conversations
column19: said Mr. de Blasio held out on having the forum until just days before the plug was pulled
column20: convinced that the event would ultimately advance the broader cause of his liberal group.\n\nOthers in the mayor\u2019s circle remain intensely committed: John Del Cecato
column21: one of Mr. de Blasio\u2019s closest advisers who is widely viewed as the most enthusiastic champion of the project
column22: defended it this week as having helped move the national political debate in a liberal direction.\n\nMr. de Blasio stressed Wednesday that he was invested in making the Progressive Agenda a success
column23: and vowed to put \u201cyears and years of effort\u201d into pressing its inequality message forward.\n\n\u201cWe are going to be doing activities all over the country and in Washington to keep pushing the issue of income inequality to the fore
column26: \u201cWe\u2019re going to keep trying new strategies until we find the ones that we think work best.\u201d\n\nAmid the public clamor over Mr. de Blasio\u2019s foray into presidential politics
column27: other aspects of the Progressive Agenda Committee have begun to take shape.\n\nThe organization
column28: which at first appeared aimed at shaping the 2016 election by pressuring Mrs. Clinton from the left
column29: has sketched out a more gradual timeline for its activities
column30: aimed at preparing to extract liberal policy achievements from the next president.\n\nGeri Prado
column31: a former A.F.L.-C.I.O. strategist who joined the Progressive Agenda Committee over the summer as its executive director
column32: said the group had begun to assemble a \u201cmessage calendar\u201d for the progressive movement aimed squarely at the first quarter of 2017.\n\n\u201cWe want to make sure that in the first 100 days of 2017
column33: people are fulfilling their promises around income inequality
column34: \u201d Ms. Prado said in an interview.\n\nMs. Prado
column36: has wooed liberal leaders with a PowerPoint presentation that ticks off a series of national ills \u2014 including the \u201cCorporatization of America\u201d \u2014 and detailed tactics to address them.\n\nThe function of the committee
column37: according to a copy of the presentation
column38: is to help provide message discipline for a diverse array of activist communities on the left.\n\nThe presentation repeatedly invokes the image of a religious congregation
column39: and states that this particular group\u2019s role is to provide \u201chymnals for the choir.\u201d\n\nThe Progressive Agenda intends to hold regular planning calls featuring a range of liberal leaders \u2014 not just Mr. de Blasio \u2014 outlining the elements of what it views as a successful progressive economic message
column40: according to people familiar with the plans. (It has already held calls to highlight research by the Roosevelt Institute
column43: a Democratic polling project focused on economic messaging.)\n\nIn mass emails
column44: organizers have urged members of the group to help create a drumbeat around key liberal priorities: One message last Friday offered up sample Twitter posts
column45: suggesting that members use social media to proclaim
column46: \u201cWall Street and the superrich are gaming the stock market.\u201d\n\nThe group has also taken steps to reduce Mr. de Blasio\u2019s presence: The mayor\u2019s name did not appear on the invitations sent to presidential candidates
column47: and organizers said that he would have played no speaking role at the forum.\n\nStill
column48: Mr. de Blasio confers with Ms. Prado at least once a week about the group\u2019s activities. And if the group is aiming to channel a broader set of voices
column50: Mr. de Blasio and the stature of his office have plainly been the animating forces behind its public activities so far.\n\nThe first glimmers of the Progressive Agenda emerged last spring
column51: when Mr. de Blasio convened an April meeting at Gracie Mansion with other left-leaning Democrats
column52: to discuss economic issues. By the next month
column53: at least two City Hall aides
column55: were involved in efforts to recruit endorsers for the Progressive Agenda
column56: according to emails obtained through public records requests.\n\nEarly on
column57: Mr. de Blasio personally solicited support for the agenda from leading Democrats. Howard Dean
column58: the former Vermont governor and presidential candidate
column59: said he joined the group because of a direct appeal from Mr. de Blasio
column60: and called it a useful gathering point for liberal leaders.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s basically trying to
column62: put together a counterweight to the right
column65: \u201cThere are not that many forums where national progressives all get together and talk.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. de Blasio\u2019s back-channel recruitment efforts also revealed his limitations as a liberal field marshal. He repeatedly sought support from Edwin M. Lee
column66: the mayor of San Francisco and a fellow Democrat
column67: telling him in a personal email that his backing would be a \u201cgreat boost\u201d to the Progressive Agenda.\n\nWhen Mr. Lee offered a noncommittal response
column68: Mr. de Blasio pressed the issue
column69: asking him to consider signing on by the following day. Mr. Lee did not.\n\nOther outreach efforts have yielded only impermanent results. Mr. Sanders
column70: whom the mayor has praised as an important spokesman for the left
column71: agreed in a phone call with Mr. de Blasio to participate in the Iowa forum. But the Sanders campaign never ultimately made a formal commitment.\n\nEven among officials who signed on to the group
column72: some have balked at promoting the Progressive Agenda with their own energies.\n\nMayor Steve Adler of Austin
column74: gave his stamp of approval to Mr. de Blasio\u2019s policy manifesto
column75: but in emails privately fretted with aides about how far to take the partnership. \u201cMuch of this is national stuff
column81: said there were areas of overlap between the Texas mayor\u2019s ideas and Mr. de Blasio\u2019s liberal platform. But
column83: \u201cThere are other things there that just aren\u2019t part of our agenda that are perceived as national political issues
column84: and not what the mayor\u2019s trying to accomplish here in Austin.\u201d"
column86: "description": "The disintegration of an Iowa forum was the most significant disappointment yet for Mayor Bill de Blasio\u2019s Progressive Agenda Committee
column88: "title": "De Blasio\u2019s Advocacy Group Pursues Ambitious Agenda Despite Setbacks"

11/12/15 08:11 PM EST
Donald Trump lashed out at Ben Carson on Thursday
column21: likening his \"pathological\" temperament to that of a child molester\u2019s. \nIn an appearance on CNN\u2019s \"Erin Burnett OutFront
column22: \" the billionaire businessman said that there is no cure for his 2016 presidential opponent\u2019s \u201cpathological temper.\u201d \nStory Continued Below\nThroughout the interview
column23: Trump took jabs at Carson\u2019s memoir.\n\u201cIt's in the book that he's got a pathological temper
column24: \" he said. \n\"That's a big problem because you don't cure that ... as an example: child molesting. You don't cure these people. You don't cure a child molester. There's no cure for it. Pathological
column25: there's no cure for that.\"\nCarson has been upfront about bursts of violent behavior in the past. In \"Gifted Hands
column26: \" Carson\u2019s autobiography published in the late 1990s
column27: he wrote that his behavior is due to a \u201cpathological temper
column28:
” which made headlines recently in relation to an anecdote from Carson’s youth about an attempt to stab a friend. 



            By 
Eliza Collins

Trump has taken issue this week with one specific passage in which Carson wrote
column29: \"I had what I only can label a pathological temper \u2014 a disease \u2014 and this sickness controlled me
column31: Trump reiterated that he was not adding anything new to the conversation separate from what Carson already penned. \n\"I'm not bringing up anything that's not in his book
column34: \u201cI'm not saying anything other than pathological is a very serious disease. And he said he's pathological.\u201d \n \u00a9 2015 POLITICO LLC"
column38: ' cites 'child molester' as example of condition"

column1: {"body": "Wading into the public\u00c2\u00a0debate over interactions between campaigns and super PACs:\u00c2\u00a0Charlie Spies
column2: the attorney for the Right to Rise super PAC backing Republican presidential candidate\u00c2\u00a0Jeb Bush.\nAttorneys for two Democratic super PACs aimed at electing congressional majorities have asked the Federal Election Commission for an advisory opinion that would clarify the\u00c2\u00a0increasingly blurry lines between campaigns and super PACs.\u00c2\u00a0Mr. Spies suggests in his comments\u00c2\u00a0to the FEC\u00c2\u00a0that the attorneys are really acting on behalf of Democratic frontrunner\u00c2\u00a0Hillary Clinton.\nThough Mr. Spies says he is intervening as an individual
column3: not on behalf of any client
column4: his comments certainly apply to Mr. Bush
column5: who headlined dozens of super PAC fundraisers before he officially announced his candidacy in June. Campaign-finance watchdog groups have filed complaints that say by raising money
column6: traveling the country and giving speeches
column7: Mr. Bush was essentially campaigning for months before he became subject to campaign finance regulations.\nMr. Bush continued to appear at Right to Rise fundraisers after he became a candidate as a \u00e2\u0080\u009cspecial guest.\u00e2\u0080\u009d The events are frequently scheduled immediately after campaign receptions in nearby homes or even in the same hotel to accommodate Mr. Bush\u00e2\u0080\u0099s hectic schedule.\nMr. Spies rejected the idea that the FEC has jurisdiction over private individuals who are not official candidates
column8: suggesting that would infringe on free speech and citing the Citizens United decision by the Supreme Court in 2010 that helped pave the way for the unlimited flow of money to super PACs.\nThe attorneys add that any regulation over non-candidates \u00e2\u0080\u009cruns the risk of unintended consequences\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u2014 such as affecting the activities of Mrs. Clinton
column10: on behalf of her family\u00e2\u0080\u0099s global charity.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe simply cannot have our clients ceding strategic advantage to individuals who have access to a global network or foreign money that can be used to fund the exploratory stages of a prospective candidate\u2019s run for office
column11:
â Mr. Spies wrote.

column1:
{"body": "BUENOS AIRESArgentina's central bank
chief accused the opposition of leveling false charges to force
him from office and vowed on Thursday to stay until the end of
his term in 2019
column2:
despite calls from the leading presidential
candidate for him to resign.
Monetary policymaker Alejandro Vanoli was accused by a state
prosecutor on Wednesday of selling U.S. dollar reserves at a
cheaper rate than that set by the international foreign exchange
futures market. The accusation has yet to go before a judge.
But it added to the pressure on Vanoli after opposition
presidential candidate Mauricio Macri
column3: the business-friendly\nmayor of Buenos Aires who is leading the opinion polls ahead of\nthe Nov. 22 election
column4: urged him to resign.\n\"My term ends in 2019 and I intend to stay until then
column6: saying the accusation \nagainst him was baseless and politically motivated.\nHe was appointed by outgoing President Cristina Fernandez
column7:
who was revered by the poor for strengthening the social safety
net and reviled by investors for her interventionist policies.
She is constitutionally barred from running for a third term
this year. Fernandez has endorsed Buenos Aires Governor Daniel
Scioli for president
column8:
but his platform of mixing Fernandez's
generous social spending with gradual free-market reforms has
not won popularity with voters.
Macri is campaigning on a mandate to unwind state controls
on the currency and trade that critics blame for stunted
investment and stalled growth in Latin America's No. 3 economy.
If Macri wins the presidency
column9:
his public show-downs with
Vanoli may continue. Macri blames Argentina's double-digit
inflation rate on Fernandez's and Vanoli's unorthodox policies.
The central bank chief denies any wrongdoing in the selling
of dollars and said in a statement on Wednesday he would
cooperate with investigators.
"The accusation from certain sectors of the opposition about
the sale of dollars in the futures market is without merit and
motivated purely by electoral politics
column10:
" the statement said.
A Macri spokesman could not be immediately reached.
With Argentina's official exchange rate of 9.6 to
the U.S. dollar 61 percent stronger than the black market rate
column11:
the pace of the peso's devaluation next year is a hot point of
contention in the presidential campaign.
Macri would unify Argentina's exchange rates at a stronger
level than the current official rate. Scioli and Vanoli say such
a sharp devaluation would erode salaries and spur inflation.
(Editing by Bernadette Baum)"
column14: Nov 12 (Reuters) - Argentina's central bank chief accused the opposition of leveling false charges to force him from office and vowed on Thursday to stay until the end of his term in..."
column16: vows to stay until term ends"

Josh Gerstein on the Courts
column17:
& More

            By 
Josh Gerstein

11/12/15 04:55 PM EST
A federal judge issued an order Thursday that will sharply ramp up the volume of documents being  released in a lawsuit demanding memos and emails from top aides to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.
U.S. District Court Judge Rudolph Contreras instructed the State Department to move toward production of 2
column18: 200 pages of documents per month in the case by next summer
column19: up from a rate of 700 pages per month he set at a hearing earlier this week. The schedule virtually guarantees that a significant volume of records about Clinton
column20: who is the leading Democratic candidate for president
column21: will be emerging through the primary and caucus season and into the heart of the general election next fall.\nThe order (posted here) came in a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit brought by Vice News reporter Jason Leopold. It originally sought virtually all records the State Department possessed pertaining to Clinton's four-year tenure as secretary.\nThe State Department already agreed to release redacted versions of about 30
column22: 000 emails Clinton kept in a private account and returned to her former agency last December at its request. Leopold has now narrowed the request to a variety of topics ranging from WikiLeaks to the Keystone XL pipeline and to emails and other records used by top aides to Clinton.\nMore details on the dispute are here.\n \u00a9 2015 POLITICO LLC"

column1: {"body": "Washington (CNN)President Barack Obama on Thursday dismissed Donald Trump's plan to enlist a \"deportation force\" to rid the country of undocumented immigrants
column2: saying it was infeasible
column3: bad optics and contrary to U.S. values.\n\"Imagine the images on the screen flashed around the world as we were dragging parents away from their children
column4: and putting them in detention centers
column5: and then systematically sending them out
column6: \" Obama said during an interview with ABC News.\n\"Nobody thinks that that is realistic
column8: that's not who we are as Americans.\"\nTrump has pointed to a more than m half-century-old deportation plan as the model for his proposal
column9: the so-called \"Operation Wetback\" instituted under President Dwight Eisenhower to move immigrants back across the Mexican border. \"Wetback\" is considered a derogatory slur for Mexicans living in the United States.\n\"I think the name of the operation tells you something about the dangers of looking backwards
column10: \" Obama said.\nIn the interview
column11: Obama said Trump's plan would cost the country billions. And he suggested Trump was using the proposal to exploit an anti-immigrant strain.\n\"There has always been a strain of anti-immigrant sentiment in America
column12: \" he said. \"It's the job of leaders not to play into that sentiment.\"\n"

column17: "title": "Obama on Trump's immigration plan: 'That's not who we are as Americans'"
